Description: Body sherd (mended from two fragments) of Attic black-figured pottery column-krater; interior glazed shiny black; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of parts of three male and two female dancers (left arm of male on far left; hand and lower part of naked female, to left; left arm and lower part of male wearing short fitted chiton in added red, to left; both hands and lower part of naked female to right; legs and lower body of male wearing red short fitted chiton, to left; the women's flesh is outlined with brown and filled with added white; below, black zone with two red bands; three drill holes on interior for clay analysis.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
The sherd belongs to the same vase as Alexandria 9317. Style and representation show strong Corinthian influence.
Bibliographic references: Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 262-3, no. B185)
Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p. 228, no. 19a)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0120) (Phase 1)
CVA Oxford II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain 9 Oxford fasicule 2 (p. 93, pl. II, no. 1)
Alexandridou 2011 / The Early Black-Figured Pottery of Attika in Context (c. 630-570BCE) (p. 123) (Naukratis 102)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
